items.title: Ladder shares DNA with Ralph + Gas Town
items.content: All three patterns share INV-001: Sequential mastery before composition. Ralph requires external state mastery (Level 2). Gas Town requires Ralph mastery (Level 4). The ladder IS the invariant made explicit.

items.title: Simplest useful version
items.content:
Minimal viable ladder: Level 0-1-3.
Skip 2 (subagents) if you don't need specialization.
Skip 4-7 if overnight automation is enough.
The full 8 levels are for those who need it all.

items.title: Ryan Carson: "Most people are Level 1 thinking they're Level 4"
items.content: Ryan's Untangle team adopted the ladder framework. Found 80% of their "Level 4" developers couldn't pass the Level 2 checkpoint. Going back to foundations improved their Ralph success rate from 40% to 90%.

items.title: At Level 5+, debugging becomes architectural
items.content:
THRESHOLD: Level 5 (multi-agent)
PHENOMENON: Failures become coordination failures, not code failures. You debug message passing, not logic.
IMPLICATION: Different debugging skills required. Can't just "read the code."

items.title: Ladder = Shu-Ha-Ri of Claude Code
items.content:
Shu (follow) = Level 0-2: Copy the patterns exactly
Ha (break) = Level 3-5: Adapt patterns to your context
Ri (transcend) = Level 6-7: Create your own patterns

If you've done martial arts, you already understand progression.

items.title: One constraint produces all 8 levels
items.content:
ROOT: LLM quality degrades with context
-> Fresh context required (Level 3+)
-> External state required (Level 2+)
-> Project context required (Level 1+)
-> Parallel isolation required (Level 6+)
-> Factory architecture required (Level 7)

The ladder IS context limits made visible.

items.title: What if levels weren't sequential?
items.content:
You'd design: Menu of capabilities, pick any.
Why this fails: Level 4 assumes Level 2 understanding. Without external state mastery, PRD loops fail in mysterious ways.
Hidden constraint: Dependencies aren't arbitrary. They're structural.

items.title: Speed vs. Foundation
items.content:
THE DILEMMA:
- Skip levels: Faster now, fragile later
- Master each: Slower now, solid later
- Partial mastery: Middle ground, middle results

HEURISTIC: If you're building on this for years, invest in foundations. One-off? Skip to what you need.

items.title: If you skip Level 1 (CLAUDE.md)
items.content:
IF: Skip project context setup
THEN: Claude doesn't know your patterns
THEN: Every session needs re-explanation
THEN: Loop iterations waste tokens on context
FINALLY: Level 3-4 costs 3x what they should

30 minutes of Level 1 saves hours at Level 4.

items.title: Steve Yegge: "100% vibe-coded"
items.content: Gas Town (Level 7) creator Steve Yegge: "I've never looked at the code my agents write. 100% vibe-coded." This is the Level 7 mindset - you're the PM, not the developer. Requires accepting you won't understand the implementation.

items.title: Molly Cantillon: Personal Panopticon
items.content: Built 8 parallel Claude instances managing different life domains. Level 6+ in production. "Each instance has its own CLAUDE.md, its own context. They coordinate through shared files." Proof that Level 6 scales beyond code.

items.title: How Level 5+ coordination fails
items.content:
100%: Perfect coordination, all tasks complete
80%: Occasional conflicts, manual resolution needed
60%: Frequent conflicts, agents duplicating work
40%: Chaos, more time fixing than building
CLIFF: Workers spawning workers (recursion)

Always include worker preambles to prevent recursion.

items.title: Level 4 + Playwright
items.content:
WORKS: Visual verification catches UI bugs at Level 4.
THE DANGER: Browser context consumes tokens. Don't run Playwright in main loop.
RECOMMENDATION: Use Playwright in subagent (Level 2) called from Ralph loop (Level 4).

items.title: Level 6 + Different Codebases
items.content:
WORKS: Worktrees isolate environments perfectly.
DANGER: Agents in different worktrees may have incompatible dependencies.
RECOMMENDATION: Use Docker per worktree if dependency isolation needed.

items.title: How Level 1 judgment evolves
items.content:
DAY 1: "CLAUDE.md seems like overhead"
WEEK 1: "Why do I keep re-explaining the same things?"
WEEK 2: "Oh, CLAUDE.md would have saved me hours"
MONTH 1: "CLAUDE.md is the foundation of everything"

Don't judge Level 1 by Day 1.

items.title: Self-calibration: Where are you?
items.content:
BEGINNER: "What's the difference between levels?"
INTERMEDIATE: "Which level am I at?"
ADVANCED: "Which level is RIGHT for this project?"
STAFF: "When should I regress to lower levels?"
EXPERT: "How do I teach my team to self-assess?"

items.title: If you skip the checkpoint at Level 3
items.content:
IF: Move to Level 4 without bash loop mastery
THEN: prd.json loops have shell errors
THEN: Time spent debugging bash, not features
THEN: Loop terminates unexpectedly
FINALLY: Morning reveals half-built features

The Level 3 checkpoint exists for Level 4 success.

items.title: When "more levels" stops helping
items.content:
Level 1-4: Each level provides clear benefit
Level 5: Benefit only if you need parallelism
Level 6: Benefit only if you need isolation
Level 7: Benefit only if you need persistent teams

THE INFLECTION: Level 4
Most developers should stop at Level 4. Higher levels require specific needs, not just ambition.

items.title: What if checkpoints were optional?
items.content:
You'd have: Self-reported level claims
Result: "Level 5" developers with Level 2 skills
Why checkpoints work: Objective verification
Hidden constraint: Self-assessment is unreliable. Verification is required.

items.title: UNSOLVED: Automated level assessment
items.content:
THE QUESTION: Can we automatically determine someone's level from their Claude usage?
WHY IT'S HARD: Usage patterns vary widely. Success criteria differ by project type.
CURRENT PRACTICE: Manual checkpoint verification. No automation yet.

items.title: UNSOLVED: Team-level progression
items.content:
THE QUESTION: How should teams progress? Same level for all? Mixed levels?
WHY IT'S HARD: Coordination between different skill levels is complex.
CURRENT PRACTICE: Teams aim for lowest-common-denominator level.

items.title: Depth vs. Breadth
items.content:
THE DILEMMA:
- Deep at Level 4: Excellent Ralph, miss parallelism
- Broad to Level 7: Know all patterns, master none
- Balanced: Adequate everywhere, exceptional nowhere

HEURISTIC: Go deep first. Mastery at one level transfers better than shallow knowledge of all.

items.title: Why Level 7 requires tmux
items.content:
ROOT: Gas Town runs 7+ concurrent agents
-> Need to monitor all simultaneously
-> Terminal multiplexing required
-> tmux is the standard tool
-> tmux proficiency becomes prerequisite

Level 7 prerequisites include non-Claude skills.

items.title: Level 7 mindset = PM frameworks
items.content: Level 7 shares INV-007: Specification over implementation with product management. You write what, agents figure out how. The same shift engineers resist in PM work is required for Gas Town success.

items.title: If the Ladder framework isn't right
items.content:
Need deep Ralph knowledge?
-> mastery-ralph-complete.md (Level 3-4 deep dive)

Need architectural decisions?
-> JUDGMENT-GUIDE.md (when to use what)

Need pattern comparisons?
-> compare-orchestration.md (Ralph vs CC Mirror vs Gas Town)

Need quick reference?
-> architecture-primitives.md (all patterns, no progression)

items.title: When to stop climbing
items.content:
Individual developer, moderate budget?
-> Stop at Level 4. Ralph is the sweet spot.

Startup, need speed?
-> Stop at Level 5. CC Mirror adds parallelism.

Solo-preneur, unlimited budget?
-> Level 7 if you accept the mindset shift.

items.title: What if you started at Level 7?
items.content:
You'd have: Massive infrastructure, no mental model
Result: Expensive chaos. Agents doing random things.
Why bottom-up works: Each level builds the mental model for the next
Hidden constraint: Understanding compounds. Infrastructure doesn't.

items.title: Ladder shares DNA with Dreyfus model
items.content: The Dreyfus skill acquisition model (Novice -> Expert) has the same structure: INV-008: Context-free rules precede situational judgment. Beginners need explicit rules. Experts develop intuition. The ladder makes this progression explicit for Claude Code.
